user_input: What are 5 things I can do when it's raining in London? I am visiting for the first time and only for a week with my husband. We love to walk, eat good food, and explore.
assistant_response:
Sure! Here are five options for things to do in London on a rainy day:

1. Visit The British Museum. Dedicated to human history, art and culture, The British Museum has over 8 million permanent objects in its collection and is spread over multiple floors and wings of its impressive Bloomsbury building. From its extensive collection of Egyptian mummies to the Rosetta Stone, there are numerous exhibitions to capture your imagination. The museum is free to enjoy, though runs separately ticketed exhibitions throughout the year, as well. 

2. Explore Spitalfields Market. Since the 17th century, traders have been operating out of this East London market selling food, art, antiques, jewellery, and so much more. Today, the covered market is a hot destination for fashion and food enthusiasts with numerous stalls and shops open every day of the week. On the weekends, the market hosts various community events including pop-up music festivals. 

3. Shop at Westfield London. Located in West London, Westfield London is an enormous shopping centre hosting roughly 320 stores and restaurants spread over 2.5 million square feet, including the high-end retail sector named The Village. In addition to a wide selection of food and shopping, there are multiple activity options including miniature golf, rock climbing, and a cinema. 

4. Visit the Barbican Centre. The Barbican Centre is a large performing arts centre in the City of London nestled in the impressive Barbican Estate, which is an impressive example of Brutalist architecture. The centre is home to both the London Symphony Orchestra and the BBC Symphony Orchestra, in addition to hosting multiple theatre performances, film screenings, and additional concerts. The public are also welcome to enjoy its library, dine in one of its three restaurants, or explore its vast indoor conservatory. 

5. Explore the Battersea Power Station. The Grade-II listed Battersea Power Station, which sits on the south bank of the Thames just west of Westminster, was recently refurbished and reopened as a shopping and leisure destination. Inside the building, there are various shops, eateries, and bard including Control Room B: a cocktail bar nestled within the original dials and controls of the power station. If there's a break in the rainy weather, the riverfront of the power station is lined with additional food stalls, and Battersea Park is a short five-minute walk away down the bank of the Thames. If the rain stays all day, though, there are plenty of activities sheltered by the power station including miniature gold, ping pong, and a cinema. 

Whether it's rain or shine, London has an endless supply of activities, sights, and eateries to ensure you have an unforgettable trip.

There are so many things about the UG that I love to say. It's got a beautiful campus, it's so green, and they give back to the community in every way.

In our dorms, you'll find so many amazing places to stay. Choose an amazing major like Philosophy, Art, or Social Studies, they're all great in their own way!

user_input: What other strange and obscure music genres can I check out?
assistant_response:
Here are some more obscure music genres to listen to:

1. The music genre known as pirate metal is a unique blend of heavy metal and sea shanties, accompanied by folk instruments like the concertina. Despite the unusual mix, bands such as Alestorm have found success in this genre and have a dedicated following.
2. Math rock is an indie rock style that utilizes complex time signatures and unusual meters. The genre emerged in the 1980s and peaked in the mid-1990s. Today, similar techniques have been adapted to pop music, resulting in the creation of the genre known as "math pop."
3. Steven Roden created the minimalist ambient music genre called "lowercase" in 2001 by manipulating and amplifying sounds made from handling paper. The genre is characterized by its quiet and unobtrusive nature and gained attention following the release of the compilation album "Lowercase-Sound" in 2002. Roden's track "Bell Is The Truth (Berlin)" exemplifies the beauty of the genre, created by tapping light bulbs in total darkness to produce bell-like sounds.
4. Witch House is a genre that doesn't have any resemblance to house music, despite the name. It was coined by Travis Egedy (aka, Pictureplane) and features slow tempo, chopped and screwed songs with elements of goth, shoegaze, hip-hop, drone, noise, and industrial. Other artists, such as Clams Casino, Holy Other, and Zola Jesus, have also incorporated Witch House elements into their music. Though the genre burned out after a few years, it remains captivating.
5. Skweee is a genre of mostly instrumental music that originated in Sweden and Finland, combining synth leads and basslines with funk and soul rhythms. Its name reflects the idea of squeezing out the grooviest sound possible. Skweee was also a major influence on dubstep during 2008-2009.

user_input: Write one paragraph about the Tlachihualtepetl pyramid. Keep it at or below 15 sentences. Include its size and when it was built. Also, include any aspects of worship it had. Include aspects of its more recent history, too. Name at least one specific year.
assistant_response: When people hear the word "pyramid," they often think of Egypt. However, the world's largest pyramid is in Cholula, Mexico. Tlachihualtepetl, also called the Great Pyramid of Cholula, is 217 feet (66 meters) tall and its base is 1,476 by 1,1476 feet (450 by 450 meters). Its total volume is 157 million cubic feet. Due to its size, it took centuries to build. It was worked on several different times between 300 BC and 700 AD. There was a temple above it to worship Quetzalcoatl - the Aztec god of learning and books. However, the temple was abandoned around the 8th or 9th century AD. Over time, it became covered with vegetation. As a result, it blended in and Spaniards first mistook it for a hill when they conquered Mexico in 1521. They replaced the temple with a church and the pyramid stayed hidden until the 1930s when the earth started to erode. Archeologists have excavated and studied many parts of the pyramid since then, including the altars. It has also become a tourist attraction since then. Thousands of people visit Tlachihualtepetl each year.

user_input:
Rewrite this like it's a personal letter from Tina Turner to a friend explaining her early solo career. 

In 1976 and 1977, Turner earned income by appearing on TV shows such as The Hollywood Squares, Donny & Marie, The Sonny & Cher Show, and The Brady Bunch Hour.[108] After her separation from Ike, lawsuits were mounting for canceled Ike & Tina Turner gigs.[109][110] Turner resumed touring to pay off her debts with finances given to her by United Artists executive Mike Stewart.[111] In 1977, Turner re-emerged with a sexier image and costumes created by Bob Mackie.[112] She headlined a series of cabaret shows at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas and took her act to smaller venues in the United States.[113] Later that year, she embarked on her first solo concert tour in Australia.[114]

In 1978, Turner released her third solo album, Rough, on United Artists with distribution in North America and Europe on EMI. That album, along with its 1979 follow-up, Love Explosion, which included a brief diversion to disco music, failed to chart, so United Artists Records and Turner parted ways.[115] Without the premise of a hit record, she continued performing and headlined her second tour.[116]

In 1979, Australian manager Roger Davies agreed to manage Turner after seeing her perform at the Fairmont Hotel in San Francisco.[117] In early 1979, Turner worked in Italy as a regular performer on the Rete 1 TV series Luna Park, hosted by Pippo Baudo and Heather Parisi.[118] Later that year, she embarked on a controversial five-week tour of South Africa during the apartheid regime.[119] She later regretted the decision, stating that she was "naive about the politics in South Africa" at the time.[120]

In October 1981, Rod Stewart attended Turner's show at the Ritz in New York City and invited her to perform "Hot Legs" with him on Saturday Night Live.[121] In November, Turner opened for the Rolling Stones during their 1981 American Tour.[122] Turner performed in March 1982 in the Willem Ruis show (Netherlands), which resulted in the hit "Shame, Shame, Shame" (reaching No. 47 in the Netherlands). In 1982 Turner's recording of the Temptations' "Ball of Confusion" for the UK production team B.E.F. became a hit in European dance clubs.[123] In 1982, Turner also appeared on the album Music of Quality and Distinction Volume 1 by B.E.F., a side project of Heaven 17, singing "Ball of Confusion". She filmed a music video for "Ball of Confusion" that aired on the fledgling music video channel MTV, becoming one of the first black American artists to gain airtime on the channel.[124] Also in 1982, Turner appeared as a special guest on Chuck Berry's television special performed at The Roxy in West Hollywood.[125]

Dear friend, 

So much happened in my early solo career. In 1976, my primary source of income came from TV appearances. You remember those, like The Hollywood Squares, Donny & Marie, The Sonny and Cher Show, and The Brady Bunch Hour? But after I left Ike, I started getting sued for all these gigs that we'd had to cancel. I had to resume touring with United Artists just to pay off my debts, but thanks to Bob Mackie I came back sexier than ever in 77! My career really took off, from cabaret shows in Vegas to tours across the US and Australia.  

Rough, my third solo album, came out in 1978 and was distributed across the U.S. and Europe! And then there was my next album, Love Explosion, which was my exploration into disco. Unfortunately, neither of these performed very well, so I ended up leaving United Artists. I still got to headline another tour, at least.

in 1979, I ran into an Australian manager named Roger Davies. After he saw me perform in San Francisco at the Fairmont Hotel, he agreed to be my manager! I was back in the international spotlight, working in Italy on Luna Park and touring in South Africa. That move of mine got a lot of flack, and to tell you the truth, I regret my naivety about the apartheid. 

Flash forward to October 1981, when Rod Stewart saw me perform in New York City and invited me to perform on Saturday Night Live with him. The next month, I opened for the Rolling Stones on their American Tour. Early the next year, I got to perform on the Willem Ruis show in the Netherlands, and my song "Shame, Shame, Shame," ended up being a hit. My cover of "Ball of Confusion" (that I recorded for B.E.F.) was really popular in European dance clubs. I even got to film an MTV music video for that song. I was one of the first black American artists on the channel. I also got to appear on Chuck Berry's television special that year. The rest, as they say, is history!

Sincerely, 
Tina Turner

user_input: Write a post offering a list of eight specific and actionable steps that a student can take to improve their performance in writing and speaking Japanese if they only know Spanish.
assistant_response:
If you are a Spanish-speaking student struggling with writing and speaking Japanese, don't worry. With these actionable steps, you'll be able to improve your Japanese language skills in no time. Here's what you need to do:

1. Invest in quality study materials: It's important to have study materials that are tailored to your level and learning style. Look for books, audio, and video resources that will help you learn Japanese.

2. Build a strong vocabulary: Learn at least 20-30 new words each day, and use them in your daily conversations and writing.

3. Master basic grammar rules: Learn basic Japanese grammar rules, including sentence structure, particles, verb conjugations, and more. Use flashcards, grammar books, and other resources to practice.

4. Use the right apps and resources: There are many Japanese language apps and resources available online, but not all of them are effective. Find the ones that work best for you, such as Duolingo, Lingodeer, or Rosetta Stone.

5. Practice daily conversation: One of the best ways to improve your speaking skills is to engage in daily conversations. Use apps like HelloTalk to find native Japanese speakers to practice with.

6. Watch Japanese TV shows and movies: Watching Japanese TV shows and movies can help you improve your listening and comprehension skills. Try to watch them without subtitles for an added challenge.

7. Immerse yourself in the language: Finally, immerse yourself in Japanese culture as much as possible. Listen to Japanese music, read Japanese books, and practice speaking and writing as often as possible.

8. Seek feedback: Find a tutor or language exchange partner who can provide feedback on your writing and speaking skills. This feedback can help you identify areas for improvement and hone your skills.

By following these steps, you can make significant progress in your Japanese language skills. Don't give up - keep practicing, and you'll see the results in no time!

user_input:
Please summarize this post. Make it easier to read and much shorter. It should only be about a paragraph or two. Use the text following this request. 

After World War II, designating the start and end dates for daylight saving time fell to state governments. Because this created many railroad scheduling and safety problems, however, Congress passed the Uniform Time Act in 1966. This law set the nationwide dates of daylight saving time from the last Sunday in April until the last Sunday in October. In 2007, Congress amended the act to expand the period in which daylight saving time is in effect from the second Sunday in March to the first Sunday in November - dates that remain in effect today.

The Uniform Time Act allows states and territories to opt out of daylight saving time, however. Arizona and Hawaii are on permanent standard time, along with Puerto Rico, the U.S. Virgin Islands, Northern Mariana Islands, Guam and American Samoa.

Now, many other states are considering whether to stop falling back and springing ahead. Several U.S. states have legislation and resolutions under consideration to support permanent standard time, while many others have been or are considering permanent daylight saving time. Legislation and resolutions for permanent standard time have increased from 15% in 2021 to 31% in 2023.

In March 2022, the U.S. Senate passed the Sunshine Protection Act  in a bid to make daylight saving time permanent. But the House did not move forward with this legislation. Florida Sen. Marco Rubio reintroduced the bill on March 1, 2023.

The spike in activity among states seeking to break from these twice-yearly changes reflects how more people are recognizing the downsides of this practice. Now, it's up to legislators to decide whether we end the time shift altogether, and to choose permanent standard or daylight saving time.
assistant_response:
After WWII, states were given the right to choose the start and end dates for daylight saving time, but this caused serious problems for rail schedules. To address this, Congress passed the Uniform Time Act in 1966 which standardized the changes, but still allowed states and territories to opt out entirely. Arizona, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and some U.S. territories decided to stay on permanent time. 

Many other states and legislators are considering abolishing daylight saving time, but no bill has passed. People are starting to recognize the problems caused by changing the time twice a year and want to move to a permanent standard time.

assistant_response:
**Soggy Yellow Spuds by Ronald A. Spudchaser** is a raw, thought-provoking story of one burlap-wrapped family of young potatoes on an emotional journey across the country. Their courage as they bounce from farm truck to semi-trailer to freight container, trading warm spring sunshine for cavernous metal walls is humbling. At one point in the story, I cried when the bag tore and the smallest potato fell to the ground during a transfer between trucks. My kids are long grown up, but my motherly heart broke. The other spuds could only watch in horror as they rolled away into a gutter. Their stoicism throughout the harrowing tale is a lesson in perseverance and bravery that people can only hope to achieve in their lifetimes.

Don't buy this book if you're looking for tepid, feel-good reading, but do buy it if you want gentle humor and beautiful descriptions of love and tenderness from an unexpectedly feisty little family. I promise that sorrow is tempered with joy and the book is well worth a read. It gets all the stars from me!

user_input: How was Peanut Butter invented?
assistant_response:
While Canadian Marcellus Gilmore Edson created peanut paste, an important precursor to peanut butter, John Harvey Kellogg was responsible for popularizing peanut butter made from raw peanuts in 1885. He created the product as a source of protein for those who couldn't otherwise chew solid food. Ambrose Straub further contributed to the product's popularity when he created a peanut-butter-making-machine which increased its viability as a mass market product.

While many people falsely credit George Washington Carver with inventing peanut butter, many of his contributions did, in fact, pave the way for its invention. If not for his discoveries of the many practical applications of peanuts, there may not have been a significant peanut industry in the United States.

user_input: What can I do to feel better? I'm not sick, I just feel sort of blah. Make me a list of things of healthy habits I can do.
assistant_response:
Here is a list of 12 healthy daily habits that you can start.

1. Get up early. Getting up early is a great habit to have. People have a natural circadian rhythm that controls certain hormones. Waking up early will help you maintain your circadian rhythm.
2. Drink water in the morning. Drinking water soon after you wake up will help keep you hydrated. Since low levels of dehydration are linked with fatigue and headaches, you should drink water when you first get up.
3. Incorporate movement into your day. Human bodies were designed to move, yet many of your jobs are sedentary. You should incorporate movement into your day because exercise has tremendous health benefits.
4. Go outside. Being outside will allow you to breathe some fresh air. The sunlight also provides vitamin D which your body needs. Deficiencies in vitamin D are linked to fatigue, low mood, and depression.
5. Sit down to eat. Digestion occurs best when you are sitting down. 
6. Walking. Although walking is often overlooked as a healthy habit, it improves fitness, and heart health, and prevents gaining weight. Walking is also linked to improved posture and circulation.
7. Cook for yourself. Cooking for yourself allows you to control what you are eating. Cooking is also a form of self-care that you can practice every day.
8. Eat some vegetables. Eating vegetables is a healthy choice. By choosing to eat vegetables, you can reduce the number of unhealthy foods you eat.
9. Limit your phone time. Studies have shown that the blue light emitted from phones leads to a reduction in melatonin which your body needs to regulate sleep. This can negatively affect your natural circadian rhythm.
10. Do some cleaning. A messy physical space around you can affect your mood. Cleaning up can reduce frustration and make it easier to cook for yourself.
11. Read something. Reading can stimulate growth, reduce stress, reduce age-related cognitive decline, and help you sleep at night.
12. Get plenty of rest. It is recommended that you get at least 8 hours of sleep at night. Low-quality sleep and lack of sleep have been linked to several ailments.

"I can't believe dancing is so hard! They always make it look easy on television," complained Fred to his twin sister Adelaide. "That's because everything on television is fake, silly! Mom said to never believe what you see on there," retorted Adelaide while attempting a pirouette that looked more like a failed attempt at scratching her back. "Still," moaned Fred, "you see the leopard siblings constantly dance in the savannah, and they make it look so easy." Fred's eyes slowly filled with tears of frustration as he stumbled over his chunky legs for the umpteenth time that morning. Adelaide giggled and claimed: "That's obviously because they don't weigh as much as us! We are just not made for cool stuff like that." 

"That's not a very nice thing to say," replied their mother, who had been observing their antics for a while without intervention. "Just because our bodies are not as lithe as the leopards, does not mean that we are less worthy. We have many other talents that the leopards wished they had." Mother Elephant, slowly making her way to her teary-eyed son, offered her trunk to him to help him back onto his feet. "We have extreme strength that is almost unparalleled in the animal world! And our trunks are amazing designs of nature that allow us to do so many different tasks that other animals could not even dream about achieving!" This statement from Mother Elephant made Adelaide take a closer look at her trunk, observing its great strength and prehensility. Fred, too, analyzed the muscles on his body and admired the force that was hiding behind his hide; his tears now almost dried. 

Mother Elephant smiled at her children, aware of the potency of her words. "We all have different strengths and weaknesses, and it is important not to feel discouraged about the latter. Just remember the things that make us unique!" she said and gave the children a warm hug before the two twins rushed back into the bushland to compare their strength in a playful battle.

user_input:
Read this article and give me a description of Eagleman. 

Eagleman is thirty-nine now and an assistant professor of neuroscience at Baylor College of Medicine, in Houston. Physically, he seems no worse for the fall. He did a belly flop on the bricks, he says, and his nose took most of the impact. "He made a one-point landing," as his father puts it. The cartilage was so badly smashed that an emergency-room surgeon had to remove it all, leaving Eagleman with a rubbery proboscis that he could bend in any direction. But it stiffened up eventually, and it's hard to tell that it was ever injured. Eagleman has puckish, neatly carved features, with a lantern jaw and modish sideburns. In Baylor's lab-coated corridors, he wears designer jeans and square-toed ankle boots, and walks with a bounce in his step that's suspiciously close to a strut, like Pinocchio heading off to Pleasure Island.

If Eagleman's body bears no marks of his childhood accident, his mind has been deeply imprinted by it. He is a man obsessed by time. As the head of a lab at Baylor, Eagleman has spent the past decade tracing the neural and psychological circuitry of the brain's biological clocks. He has had the good fortune to arrive in his field at the same time as fMRI scanners, which allow neuroscientists to observe the brain at work, in the act of thinking. But his best results have often come through more inventive means: video games, optical illusions, physical challenges. Eagleman has a talent for testing the untestable, for taking seemingly sophomoric notions and using them to nail down the slippery stuff of consciousness. "There are an infinite number of boring things to do in science," he told me. "But we live these short life spans. Why not do the thing that's the coolest thing in the world to do?"
assistant_response: Eagleman is 39 with puckish features including a lantern jaw, styled sideburns, flashy jeans and ankle boots. Physically, he has completely recovered from his childhood fall that broke his nose. He is obsessed with time and is an assistant professor of neuroscience at Baylor College of Medicine.

user_input: I want to make a video game in Python! Can you show me how to make a game window with a player character in python?
assistant_response:
Sure! We'll use the Pygame software package to simplify the game structure, which you may need to install separately.

import pygame
pygame.init()

# Set the width and height of the screen
size = (800, 600)
screen = pygame.display.set_mode(size)

# Set the title of the window
pygame.display.set_caption("A Basic Game in Python!")

# Load the background image
background_image = pygame.image.load("background.png").convert()

# Load the character image
character_image = pygame.image.load("character.png").convert_alpha()

# Set the beginning position of the character
character_position = [100, 100]

# Main game loop starts here
running=True
while running:
    # Handle quit event
    for event in pygame.event.get():
        if event.type == pygame.QUIT:
            running=False

    # Draw the background image
    screen.blit(background_image, [0, 0])

    # Draw the character sprite at the beginning position
    screen.blit(character_image, character_position)

    # Update the screen
    pygame.display.flip()

# Quit the game
pygame.quit()

This script creates a window with a resolution of 800x600, draws a background and a character, and then runs until the user quits. This is a good base for your new Python video game, to which you can add various features depending on your goals for the game. 

Note that both the background and character image should be in the same directory as the game file.

Happy PyGaming!

user_input:
Turn the pasted text into a 10-question quiz that has answers.

It's important to recognize the symptoms of schizophrenia and seek help as early as possible. People with schizophrenia are usually diagnosed between the ages of 16 and 30, after the first episode of psychosis. Starting treatment as soon as possible following the first episode of psychosis is an important step toward recovery. However, research shows that gradual changes in thinking, mood, and social functioning often appear before the first episode of psychosis. Schizophrenia is rare in younger children.

Schizophrenia symptoms can differ from person to person, but they generally fall into three main categories: psychotic, negative, and cognitive.

Psychotic symptoms include changes in the way a person thinks, acts, and experiences the world. People with psychotic symptoms may lose a shared sense of reality with others and experience the world in a distorted way. For some people, these symptoms come and go. For others, the symptoms become stable over time. Psychotic symptoms include:

Hallucinations: When a person sees, hears, smells, tastes, or feels things that are not actually there. Hearing voices is common for people with schizophrenia. People who hear voices may hear them for a long time before family or friends notice a problem.
Delusions: When a person has strong beliefs that are not true and may seem irrational to others. For example, individuals experiencing delusions may believe that people on the radio and television are sending special messages that require a certain response, or they may believe that they are in danger or that others are trying to hurt them.
Thought disorder: When a person has ways of thinking that are unusual or illogical. People with thought disorder may have trouble organizing their thoughts and speech. Sometimes a person will stop talking in the middle of a thought, jump from topic to topic, or make up words that have no meaning.
Movement disorder: When a person exhibits abnormal body movements. People with movement disorder may repeat certain motions over and over.
Negative symptoms include loss of motivation, loss of interest or enjoyment in daily activities, withdrawal from social life, difficulty showing emotions, and difficulty functioning normally.

Negative symptoms include:

Having trouble planning and sticking with activities, such as grocery shopping
Having trouble anticipating and feeling pleasure in everyday life
Talking in a dull voice and showing limited facial expression
Avoiding social interaction or interacting in socially awkward ways
Having very low energy and spending a lot of time in passive activities. In extreme cases, a person might stop moving or talking for a while, which is a rare condition called catatonia.
These symptoms are sometimes mistaken for symptoms of depression or other mental illnesses.

Cognitive symptoms include problems in attention, concentration, and memory. These symptoms can make it hard to follow a conversation, learn new things, or remember appointments. A person's level of cognitive functioning is one of the best predictors of their day-to-day functioning. Health care providers evaluate cognitive functioning using specific tests.

Cognitive symptoms include:

Having trouble processing information to make decisions
Having trouble using information immediately after learning it
Having trouble focusing or paying attention
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has recognized that having certain mental disorders, including depression and schizophrenia, can make people more likely to get severely ill from COVID-19. Learn more about getting help and finding a health care provider.

1. At what age range are people usually diagnosed with schizophrenia?  

Answer: 16-30

2. True or False, Schizophrenia is common in young children. 

Answer: False 

3. What are the three main categories of schizophrenic symptoms? 

Answer: Psychotic, Negative, and Cognitive 

4. Which one of these is NOT a psychotic symptom? 

A. Hallucinations 
B. Movement Disorder
C: Lack of interest 
D. Delusions 

Answer: C 

5. What is catatonia? 

Answer: A rare condition where a person stops moving or talking. 

6. The negative symptoms of schizophrenia are often mistaken as symptoms of what other mental illness? 

Answer: Depression 

7. A 21-year-old male believes that the radio is sending special messages to him. What psychotic symptom is he expressing? 

A. Delusions
B. Hallucinations 
C. Catatonia 
D. Anhedonia 

Answer: A 

8. True or false, Cognitive symptoms include problems in attention and memory. 

Answer: True 

9. What is one of the best predictors of a person's day-to-day function? 

Answer: Their cognitive function 

10. A 23-year-old female has been admitted to the hospital. When the doctor comes to evaluate her, she is seen talking to herself and states that Taylor Swift is in the room with her. What psychotic symptom is she expressing? 

Answer: Hallucinations

user_input: Who was John T. Scope?
assistant_response: John T. Scopes was a Tennessee school teacher who went to trial for teaching students Darwin's "Theory of Evolution". In March of 1925, the state legislature in Tennessee passed a bill that banned all teaching of evolution in any educational institution throughout the state. John Scopes agreed to stand as a defendant in a test case to challenge the law. He was arrested on May 7, 1925, and charged with teaching the theory of evolution. The trial turned out to be one of the most sensational cases of the 20th century in America. Approximately 1000 people and more than 100 newspapers packed inside the courtroom daily to watch the trial that only lasted eight days. In the end, the jury returned the verdict of guilty in less than nine minutes. John Scopes was fined $100.

user_input: Okay, AI ChatBot, I am writing my very first college essay. The topic can be anything I choose, but that's not what I need help with. I was never a very strong writer in high school, so my confidence is pretty low. Can you brainstorm five things to focus on to improve my essay writing? Do not give me content-based tips; I want them strictly to be about essay writing.
assistant_response:
Here are five things you can focus on to improve your essay writing:

1. Write a Strong Thesis: A thesis is an articulate statement of your central argument. Write your thesis sooner rather than later to focus your research and write around a central point without being distracted by tangential ideas.
2. Create an Outline: Writing an outline fleshes out the core ideas in your essay, helping you to focus on each section and the relevant data/quotes when you write your rough draft. 
3. Use and Cite Outside Sources: Most college essays necessitate some level of research, and in order for your paper to be compelling, you will need to support your claims using quotes and, in some cases, statistics and data. Find a reputable source that provides helpful, relevant information that you can quote or incorporate to develop your writing. Just be certain to cite any sources you include, whether those sources are direct or indirect.
4. Create a Rough Draft: A rough draft translates your outline into a structured essay with an introduction, body paragraphs, and conclusion.
5. Proofread: Proofreading is important even for the most accomplished writer. Review your paper carefully, both editorially and structurally. Correct grammar and punctuation as you go and make sure that the structure of your essay is cohesive, relevant, and compelling.

user_input:
Reduce this article from 488 to less than 150 words by summarizing and focusing on the essential facts.

In this fact sheet, students will learn about the people who became actors, what an average day was like and more.

Actors

The life of an actor changed dramatically during Shakespeare's lifetime. At first actors toured in companies, travelling the country to perform in towns and cities and in private homes. By the time Shakespeare died, London had several permanent theatres where the actors performed, drawing in huge audiences. Yet, despite the popularity of play-going, the acting profession had a bad reputation. Actors were seen as unruly and a threat to a peaceful society.

Who became an actor?

In Shakespeare's time acting was a profession only open to boys and men. Women were acting elsewhere in Europe but they were not allowed to perform in public theatres in England until 1660. In an Elizabethan production boys would play the female parts, like Ophelia in Hamlet or Desdemona in Othello, whilst occasionally men would play the older women. There were many more actors working across the country at the time, but these are some of the best known Elizabethan actors: Richard Burbage, Edward Alleyn, Robert Armin, William Kemp and Nathan Field.

What was an actor's training?

Many actors began their careers as young boys. They could join a company as an apprentice and be taught by one of the more senior actors within the company. Actors were expected to be able to sword fight, sing and dance, as well as having a good memory for learning lines.

How big was a company?

Company sizes varied, depending on where the company was working and how wealthy the company was. A wealthy company, when working in a theatre, might have 8- 12 senior members called sharers, 3-4 boys, a number of hired players (hired men) and then stage hands, tiremen (who would help the actors dress back stage) and some musicians. Actors would join a company under the patronage of a monarch (like the Queen's Men) or a nobleman, such as the Lord Admiral's Men or the Lord Chamberlain's Men. 

Where did a company work?

Most companies were based in London, using one of the permanent theatres. Sometimes the theatres were closed, for example when there was a plague in the city, and so companies would then go on tour. Mostly they toured England, but companies did also go abroad, particularly to the Netherlands and Germany.

What did an actor earn?

Many theatre companies operated a shareholder system. Sharers in a company earned more than the hired men. Shakespeare was a sharer of the Chamberlain's Men, later the King's Men, and so shared the costs and also the profits the company made. Actors' earnings also depended on where the company was playing. The company made more money in London than in the country, so could pay actors higher wages. In 1597 the actor William Kendall was paid 10 shillings a week in London but only 5 shillings in the country.
assistant_response: Before Shakespeare's lifetime, actors, who were only men or boys, toured in companies. By the time of Shakespeare's death, Actors, though seen as having bad reputations, performed at several permanent playhouses in London. In Elizabethan productions, the roles of females were played by boys and occasionally, when an older female was required, by men. Boys often started their careers in their youth by becoming an apprentice. Older actors would teach them sword fighting, singing, and dancing. Among the most famous Elizabethan actors were Richard Burbage, Edward Alleyn, Robert Armin, William Kemp, and Nathan Field. In a wealthy company under the patronage of a monarch or nobleman, a senior actor - of which there were 8-12 - could earn as much as 10 shillings a week for performances in London.

Is the following statement true or false? Keeping a plant healthy reduces the risk of pest infestations. 

Use the following passage to answer the question.

How to Treat Yellowing Leaves on Snake Plant
Once you narrow down the reason your snake plant has yellow leaves, you'll want to address the issue quickly to keep your plant healthy. However, yellow leaves won't turn green again even if the issue is remedied, so it's best to cut them off with sharp, sanitized pruners or scissors at the base of the plant.

Check your plant's soil moisture. If the soil feels soggy and you've been watering frequently, overwatering could be to blame. Let the soil dry out completely before watering again. In extreme cases, you may need to repot the plant in fresh soil and inspect the roots for signs of rot.

If your snake plant's leaves look sunburned and the plant is getting direct sunlight, move it further away from the light source or use a sheer curtain to filter the light and make it less intense. Address inconsistent temperature by keeping the plant away from drafty areas and putting it in a space with a more consistent temperature.

Inspect your snake plant regularly for signs of pests. Remove insects with blasts of water or a cotton swab dipped in rubbing alcohol, then use neem oil or horticultural soap to prevent them from coming back. Keep your plant healthy going forward to lessen the likelihood that pests will attack.

If you haven't fertilized or refreshed your snake plant's soil in a few years and other causes don't apply, repot it with fresh soil. If the plant seems potbound, use a pot one size larger or divide the plant and repot it in its original container. If you suspect overfertilizing is the issue, flush your plant's soil several times with water to remove excess nutrients. Going forward, only fertilize your snake plant twice per year in spring and summer.

user_input: I'd like you to write a short story where Superman and Batman argue about the best pizza topping when, in the end, they are called away before finishing.

Superman and Batman were enjoying a nice day off from the Justice League. Strolling around the complex together they started talking about some of their favorite foods.

"Let me tell you, Superman, nothing beats a New York-style pizza with cheese, pepperoni, and sausage. Just the right amount of toppings where you can taste them and still fold up the slice," Batman said to his pal.

Superman stopped in his tracks. "Surely you jest, Bruce. That is the most basic pizza I've ever heard of, and there isn't even a single veggie on it."

"Yeah, no veggies; that's why it's so good. What do you put on yours?"

"Well, I like broccoli."

Batman blinked a few times in quick succession. "Broccoli, you're kidding, right?"

"Well not just broccoli, I also like it with some onions and a white sauce."

"White sauce on a pizza, you're one of those guys, huh?"

"It's delicious! Trust me. There's something about how it just melds together with the crispy crust. That's another thing; it has to be crispy. Not one of those floppy New York pizzas."

"I don't even know what to say to that. You can't even fold your pizza?"

"No, of course not; who wants to fold their pizza? I like a nice cracker-style crust that crunches when you bite into it"

"Superman, my friend, that is not pizza. I don't know what that is, but it isn't pizza."

"How about this, let's fly out of here to your favorite spot and you grab two slices in your style. Then we'll fly to mine, and you give the broccoli a chance."

Batman put his hand to his chin and pondered the request. But before he could reply, an alarm sounded in the halls.  Superman, noticing Batman's flummoxed expression, gave him a nod and then they both ran down the corridor to the security room.

Reaching the bank of computers and monitors, they could see a new report of an explosion in Mumbai of a potentially alien origin.

Superman looked at Batman and said, "Well, there's no pizza in Mumbai but you better believe we're getting a slice when we're done."

"You got it," Batman replied, "Let's suit up and save the day."

user_input: Describe a contest between two girls that are trying to win ownership over a dog.
assistant_response:
The day was clear and bright. They should have met at dawn because Hannah said that was the correct time for duels, but Bella refused to get up so early. The duel was, therefore, set for nine o'clock. Neither Hannah nor Lizzie slept that night, but each was quietly sure she would win. Hannah had been practicing calling Vanilla to her for weeks, and Vanilla was pretty good at it now. She knew that when Lizzie had had the puppy, it was too young to train - Vanilla couldn't possibly go to Lizzie. But Vanilla could sometimes be naughty. Could she be sure? 

At the corner shop, Hannah bought a pouch of aniseed balls and put them in her pocket where the smell would surely be carried on her hands: dogs were supposed to find aniseed irresistible. 'I did want some anyway,' Hannah told herself. But it wasn't true - she would never have bought aniseed balls for herself. Hannah was really cheating. 

Lizzie wished she hadn't agreed to a duel, but she couldn't get out of it now. She let Hannah take Fudge - her name for the puppy - home that night because she reckoned that Fudge would rush to greet her and not go to Hannah. But she had no qualms about putting a piece of raw steak in her pocket. It felt horrible, and she knew she would get into trouble with Bella over it. Well, too bad; this was an emergency. 

Hannah had written out the rules carefully on a bit of paper. She read them out in her thin, clear voice. One or two people stopped to watch, but when some children ran into the dueling area, Bella shoed them away. The two girls would stand forty paces apart, with Bella in the middle holding the puppy. Then, when they were ready, Bella would give the signal and let go. Neither Lizzie nor Hannah was allowed to move, but they would each call the puppy's name. Whichever of them she ran to would be the winner and the puppy's owner. Bella was the judge, and her decision was final. 

'Twenty paces, then,' said Hannah. They counted out the steps and turned to face each other. Bella looked at both the girls to check they were ready. First one, and then the other nodded. 'Now!' Bella said and let go.

user_input: Write a short story about a man walking down a road. Give it a mysterious ending.
assistant_response:
Nigel set off at a fair trot. He'd put on his favorite loafers and his lovely brown cardigan. It was a cool day, but that didn't faze him at all. The wind danced over his bald head, and tussled his limp and greasy hair.

Nigel was in a fantastic mood today. He felt truly alive for the first time in 40 years. As an accountant, there wasn't a huge amount of variation or interest in his work. Numbers came in, and these days robots did all the work. Never mind, Nigel kept walking. 

He recalled better times when his hair had been thicker and his belly tighter. He was the master of the calculator, a colossal computer that sang machine rhythm for him and him alone. 

In a way, Nigel reflected, he had been the architect of his own downfall. He made a machine that made him redundant. It doesn't even make him rich. But that's Luddite nonsense. If you're a plow maker, making a plow-making machine doesn't make you redundant, it makes your job more ... future-y. 

The road bent and he could see the long straight of the beach up ahead. Long straight gravel road. Long straight horizon. He smelled the salty sea air. 

He managed to get to the little place after Marg passed. She had never wanted to live at the beach, and that was fair. It is inconvenient to be so far from the semblance of civilization, but there it was. The sea. 

The sea called to Nigel. When he was young, it had called him away to America. When he was finished getting his fancy degrees, it called him home. Now the sea called to him again, so Nigel kept walking.  

The crunch of gravel gave way to the soft pushing of buffalo grass, then the squish-crunch of sand. The bay embraced him in a grey arc, bounded on both ends by tall, withering cliffs. 

Nigel walked a little further and felt his loafers dampen with the salt water. Soon he felt his knees and skin prickle with the lapping water. Then his cardigan got wet. Then his grizzled chin and his lank hair became the playthings of the sea. 

Nigel kept walking.

2. Make a running jump: The most straightforward option, the character could run as fast as possible and attempt to leap across the chasm. However, they may not be able to clear the gap, falling down the chasm to their peril. They could also simply trip some distance before the chasm. This may be useful if you do not wish to incur a "game over" screen for this rash decision by the player.
3. Lay a log across the chasm: The player could command the character to look for a suitably long log to balance across the chasm. Alternatively, they could attempt to chop down a tree over the chasm. This would not work if the tree was of insignificant length to cover the gap or if the character was not strong enough to lift up and drop a sufficiently long log. 
4. Look for a way around: The player could command the character to simply walk along the chasm until they find a way across. This could fail if there is no way across, or if the path across is visible but not accessible. This could be due to a number of reasons, such as a rapidly moving river or a significant elevation difference. 
5. Acquire a vehicle: The player could command the character to look for a vehicle. This would not be a successful solution if they failed to find a vehicle capable of crossing the chasm or if the vehicle that they found was not in working order. However, a wrecked vehicle could serve as a useful clue or source of materials for the actual solution to this puzzle.

user_input: What is the International Atomic Time (TAI), and how does it differ from Coordinated Universal Time?
assistant_response:
International Atomic Time is a high-precision time standard based on the measurements of more than 300 atomic clocks located in more than 60 metrology institutes and observatories around the world. These atomic clocks use the vibrations of atoms to keep time with extreme accuracy, thereby providing a much more consistent measure of time than methods based on the rotation of our planet or its revolution around the sun.

Coordinated Universal Time is the time standard used in aviation, computing, navigation, weather forecasting, and many other fields. Unlike TAI, which is purely atomic in nature, UTC is closely aligned with mean solar time (a modern replacement for Greenwich Mean Time) and accounts for variations in Earth's rotational speed by occasionally introducing "leap seconds". While TAI ticks away uniformly, the Earth's rotation gradually slows down over time. This means that UTC, which is pegged to the Earth's rotation, occasionally falls out of sync with TAI. To correct this, a "leap second" is added to UTC approximately every 18 months, although the exact timing is determined by the International Earth Rotation and Reference Systems Service (IERS).

user_input: Come up with some review criteria for my game review site. What sections would I split them up into?
assistant_response:
I am happy to help with your game review site. Here are some criteria for you to divide your game reviews into:

1. Plot/World/Setting: Does the game have a plot? If not, what underpins the world of the game? How is the world itself, what is the narrative context (if there is any) of the gameplay? Is the game well-written and interesting? Does it have good dialogue and believable characters? Are your goals compelling?
2. Visuals: What is the art style of the game? Does the art style appear coherent? Are the graphics cutting-edge or dated? Is there a variety of settings for players to tweak the performance? How does the game perform on a range of hardware?
3. Gameplay: What sort of game is it? Does it fall into an established gameplay genre? Is the game difficult? Is there multiplayer? Is it fun and compelling to play? Which parts are more entertaining than the other parts? What elements work well, and which ones do not? 
4. Difficulty: Is the game difficult to play? How difficult? Would the game appeal to a more hardcore or casual audience? Is it expected for some players to not be able to complete certain sections of the game due to the difficulty? 
5: Length: How long is the game? How much time would it take a player to complete if they were aiming to do everything? What if they were only aiming to complete the main story? Are certain gameplay elements time limited? 
6. Audio: How is the sound design? Is it fitting and immersive? Is it generic and repetitive? Is there a soundtrack? Were any songs or tracks from the soundtrack memorable? Does it adequately convey the mood and setting of the game?
7. Etcetera: Does the game come with any extras? Were there any major technical issues or difficulties with purchasing the game that your audience should know of? Is the game unusually expensive or low-priced? Is there a relevant controversy surrounding the development of the game? How is the accessibility of the game for handicapped gamers?

1. Sports Leagues. Given your interest in being active outdoors, consider joining a recreational sports league. Emily put her pen to the creased paper, her heart hammering in her throat. As the ink flowed freely, stroke after stroke, an image began to form. It was of a hummingbird. When Emily was done, she sat back and stared hard at the scrap bit of paper in front of her. Time ticked away on her wall clock and she stared hard.

When a whole minute had passed and nothing happened, Emily was ready to give up and put her things away. And then the paper rustled. So slowly, subtly - she wouldn't have noticed if she wasn't watching so carefully. It fluttered again and then all at once the paper scrunched up. Emily jerked back in her rickety, old chair, her eyes wide, and watched the paper twist and crumple and suddenly it burst up into the air, whizzing around. 

Emily let out a cry of delight, watching as a hummingbird slowly came into being, turning from a crumpled-up paper ball into a real hummingbird. Her face was split out in a wide smile as the beautiful, green and blue bird slowly came to land on her shoulder. The bird gently nuzzled her cheek before hopping away to peek curiously at her face. 

Emily pets the hummingbird carefully, taking note of how real and warm it felt with her fingers. With her pen held tighter in her hand, she turned to her notepad and considered what to draw next.

user_input: Write a short explanation of how Netflix used to work in 2000.
assistant_response:
Netflix, which was originally founded in 1997, was up and running properly by the year 2000. At that time, the platform didn't stream movies online but instead offered DVD rentals through the mail. 

Here's how it worked: You would sign up for Netflix on their website with your card information and address. Then, you would pay a monthly subscription and order movies to be delivered to your house. 

You created a list of the movies you wanted to see on the Netflix website, and within the various packages, you could have anywhere from 1-4 DVDs at a time. Once you watched the movie of your choice, you would send the DVD back with a prepaid shipping label and wait for the next movie on your list to be delivered. 

At the time, Netflix offered more than 5,000 movie titles, which was considered extremely impressive. Especially compared to a local Blockbuster video store which would only have a few hundred. 

Netflix was extremely popular in 2000, and the system continued successfully until 2007 when they began offering online streaming.

user_input: Write a 3-day itinerary for a trip to Glacier National Park. Have a bullet point for each day and an explanation of the things to do that day. I'm an avid hiker so I'm up for lots of hiking. I want to spend most of my time on hikes. I've already been to Lake McDonald so don't include that.
assistant_response:
1. Day One. 
All Day: Hike to Iceberg Lake. This is an out-and-back 9.7-mile hike in the Many Glacier area of the park. The elevation gain is 1,275 feet, and the trail is rated as moderate. You'll begin with a steep uphill section, but after that, the trail levels out. This hike is an all-day event, but it is worth the effort. Pack a lunch, and enjoy some quiet time as you take in the glacier in all of its glory. The trail can be busy during the summer, but due to its length, it's not as popular as some other trails. Once you arrive at the lake, keep following the trail around to the left and you'll find some nice private spots where you can escape the crowds. Don't forget your swimsuit or a change of clothes - it's hard to resist jumping in the bone-chilling water to cool off. 

2. Day Two.
Morning: Hike to Virginia Falls. At 3.6 miles roundtrip and only about 525 feet of elevation gain, this is a hike that gives you a lot of bang for your buck. You'll see St. Mary falls along the way, which is a beautiful waterfall with strikingly blue water, and you'll also see smaller unnamed falls around almost every turn as you get closer to Virginia Falls. 

Afternoon: Hike the Trail of the Cedars and keep going to Avalanche Lake. This laid-back hike starts with the Trail of the Cedars, a short 1-mile boardwalk trail that offers some lovely views. You'll eventually reach a sign that points to another trail that will take you to Avalanche Lake. The hike to this lake is 4.5 miles out-and-back with about 760 feet of elevation gain. It's well worth the effort because at the end you're rewarded with a gorgeous view of the lake and a stunning mountain backdrop. The way the light hits the mountains in the late afternoon and early evening is beautiful, and you may avoid the crowds a bit by starting later in the day. Look closely - you may even see some waterfalls in those mountains!

3. Day Three.
All Day: Hike to Grinnell Glacier. While this hike can be made easier by taking a boat to shave off 3.4 miles of hiking, the first part of the trail is flat and offers views that are worth the extra mileage. The hike is 10.6 miles long in total, with an elevation gain of about 1,600 feet. It's the most strenuous hike on this itinerary. You'll start off walking around Swiftcurrent Lake and Lake Josephine. Then the climbing starts, and the views just keep getting better. Start the trail early so you can take your time and enjoy a rest once you make it to Grinnell Glacier. The hike is popular, but there's a lot to explore once you reach the glacier. Don't just stop where the trail ends - keep walking around the edge of the lake to find a nice spot to sit back and enjoy the view you worked so hard for!

Polly the poodle has pink hair that often makes her stand out in a crowd. She's the only pink poodle most other dogs have seen, so they often stare or talk about her. It makes Polly feel shy and self-conscious because she doesn't like the attention. 

Holly the husky noticed Polly standing away from all of the other dogs and often looking down. That made Holly sad, so she went over to talk to Polly. 

Holly asked Polly, "Why don't you come over with our group?" 

"I feel a little out of place," Polly answered. "Everyone is looking at me." 

"That's just because you're so beautiful, Polly," Holly said. "We've never seen a pink poodle, and we are so amazed!" 

Holly and her friends made Polly realize her difference is what makes her so special. Polly started to perk up and gain confidence. From now on, Polly is going to walk in a room knowing her unique quality makes her beautiful, and that it's okay to be different.

user_input: I'm trying to write a scene, but I have a plot ready. Please help me write a scene where David has been waiting for seven hours since he placed a note in Betty's desk, and when he suddenly hears a noise coming from the desk, he discovers that the note he placed there is gone. He is shocked and unable to understand how this could be possible. David decides to stay in the room until he gets answers. Two hours later, he hears a swishing noise and sees pieces of material swirling in the air, eventually forming into Betty. She is unconscious, and David rushes to her side. Gradually, the color returns to her face, and she regains consciousness. Betty asks David if he loves her, and he confirms that he does, taking a moment to tuck a stray curl behind her ear. The scene should be under 400 words and there should be dialogues between these characters.
assistant_response:
David seats himself in an antique chair in the corner of the room. It's been 7 hours since he placed the note on the desk. As he leans back in the chair thinking about the reality of this, he unexpectedly hears a noise coming from the desk. He leans forward listening, but hears nothing else. He walks silently to the desk. Opening the cover, then the drawer, he's shocked. The note he put in there is gone. Staggering backward he leans over taking a deep breath. Standing, he runs his fingers through his hair in utter bewilderment. Pacing back and forth in front of the desk, he begins reasoning with himself. I'm here, and I don't see anyone else. How can this be? He stands gaping at the desk. Walking back to the chair, he decides he will not move an inch from this room until he gets answers.

Two hours later, he hears a swishing noise. He sits straight up in the chair and watches in astonishment as pieces of the material circle into the wind settling to the floor. Once the pieces merge, he sees it's Betty. Running to her quickly, he finds her unconscious. He picks her head up and cradles it in his arms. Staring at her he sees she's pale. Gradually her face returns to normal. Calling her name, her eyes flutter open. 

"David, is that you?"

"Yes, my love. I'm here."

Closing her eyes, she lies silent.

"Betty, are you okay? Talk to me."

Opening her eyes again she replies, "Yes. I'm okay. It takes a while for me to gain strength from the travel. Just give me a minute. Each trip gets harder and harder to come out of the daze."

Leaning down to kiss her lips gently, he says, "It's okay, take your time. I'll wait." 

After about 15 minutes, she gets the strength to sit up. Holding her forehead, she abates the nausea. Taking deep breaths, she feels herself returning to normal. David helps her up. Their eyes meet. Rachel asks, "You love me?"

Surprised to hear that is the first thing she says coming out of her tranced state, he laughs. "Yes, Rachel, I do." He moves her over to a settee. Seated beside her, he takes the curl falling in her face and pushes it behind her ear.

user_input: My sibling and I are having an argument about if cats or dogs are better. I happen to know for a fact that cats are better, I just need some facts that prove it. Brainstorm a list of at least half a dozen things about cats and state how each one makes them better than dogs.
assistant_response:
I'm sorry to hear that you and your sibling are arguing. Here are some facts about why cats are better than dogs: 
1. Purring. This is something cats do that dogs are not physically capable of doing. It has also been proven that purring can lower your stress levels and your blood pressure. 
2. Quieter. A cat isn't going to howl at the moon, bark at anyone who knocks at the door, or anything else. While a cat might meow on occasion, they are much quieter than dogs. 
3. Less Care. Even though cats do have litterboxes, this is far less trouble than having to walk a dog every day and give it plenty of exercise. You also don't have to take a cat outside to use the bathroom when it is raining outside. 
4. Less Space. Cats do not need huge amounts of space. Even if you want to set up a play area for them, this can be vertical instead of sprawled out over the floor. Also, cat toys are usually smaller than dog toys, and a cat will take up less space on your bed than most dogs will. 
5. Less Food. Cats don't eat as much food as dogs do, so their food lasts longer and will probably be cheaper than a dog's food. 
6. Less Destruction. A bored cat is far less likely to damage something it shouldn't. This is compared to dogs, who might chew on the furniture or any number of other things. 
7. Cleaner. Cats rarely need baths due to the fact that they do a great job of keeping themselves clean. They certainly aren't going to be playing in the mud or tracking dirt into the house, even if you let them outside. 
I hope this can help put an end to your argument.

user_input: I want to whiten my teeth, but I don't want to use those chemical strips they sell at the store. So can you write four different ways to whiten teeth naturally? Explain how to use each method. {Number}.{Method}:{Description}
assistant_response:
1. Baking Soda: A tried and true tactic is brushing your teeth with baking soda. Mix one teaspoon of baking soda with two teaspoons of water to create a paste, and brush your teeth several times a week to see the effects. 
2. Oil Pulling: To oil pull, place about one tablespoon of coconut oil in your mouth. Then, swish the oil around for between 15-20 minutes. While some people don't love the taste, it can certainly whiten your teeth over time. 
3. Hydrogen Peroxide: Many toothpastes have hydrogen peroxide as a whitening agent, but you can use it straight from the bottle for more intense effects. Make sure you're using 1.5% or 3% peroxide, and if you have 3%, it's best to dilute it with a bit of water. 
4. Citrus Peels: You can use lime, lemon, orange, or banana peels to whiten your teeth by simply rubbing the inside of the rinds directly onto the teeth.

user_input: Pretend you're a wizard. Give me a spell to make myself more eloquent. I'd like some background as well.
assistant_response:
SPELL TO AID VERBAL COMMUNICATION

Please be aware that this does not constitute medical advice, and is for entertainment purposes only. 

YOU WILL NEED:
- One charcoal disk in a fireproof dish
- One silver or white candle, 6-8"/15-20 cm in length
- Matches or a lighter
- White sandalwood incense
- Nine clary sage leaves
- One 18"/45 cm length of black sewing thread
- One teaspoon of honey
- One cup/250 ml of boiling water

PURPOSE:
To bestow the gift of clear and persuasive speech.

BACKGROUND:
This is the magical equivalent of the Blarney stone - a magical stone in Ireland which, if kissed, is said to impart the "gift of the gab," or the ability to charm with words. Clary sage, or Salvia sclarea, the main ingredient of the spell, is said to confer wisdom as well as the gift of clarity, both important ingredients in the power of clear and persuasive speech. Used as an herbal remedy, it enhances confidence and aids perception.

The power of good speakers was recognized by many ancient cultures, particularly in those traditions whose survival depended on the skills of storytellers, bards, priests, and priestesses. The Celts particularly prized the skills of speech, and the power attributed to skilled speakers. The ability to always speak fair words and to charm any company is also said to be the gift of the fairies, or the "good folk."

HOW TO CAST THE SPELL

TIMING:
This charm is best performed on a waxing moon for the increase and on a Monday.

CASTING THE SPELL:

1. Cast a circle.
2. Light the charcoal disk and candle, saying:
   "Power of the old ones
    The high ones
    The low ones
    Power of the moon
    Bestow fair speech
    And it harm none."
3. Sprinkle sandalwood onto the charcoal disk and add three clary sage leaves, saying:
   "This I offer to the old ones."
4. Bind three leaves together with thread and place them beneath the candle, saying:
   "This I offer to the moon."
5. Place three leaves in a cup and pour on a teaspoon of honey. Then fill it with boiling water, saying:
   "This I offer to myself."
6. At the next full moon, take the bound leaves outside. Offer them up to the moon, kiss them, then cast them into a natural water source as soon after as possible.

She won her second Nobel Prize, in chemistry, for the discovery of two elements: polonium and radium. She died on July 4, 1934.

user_input: How does the lack of an atmosphere on the Moon affect the temperatures on its surface?
assistant_response: The Moon lacks a substantial atmosphere. This absence greatly impacts its surface temperature, leading to one of the most extreme thermal environments in the solar system. During the lunar daytime, the surface temperature can rise to around 253 degrees Fahrenheit. Conversely, in the lunar nighttime, the temperature can drop as low as -243 degrees Fahrenheit. The stark contrast is due to the absence of an atmosphere, which on Earth helps distribute heat and mitigate temperature extremes. These intense temperature swings present significant challenges for human exploration and potential habitation. For astronauts, their spacesuits must be designed to withstand these temperature extremes. Similarly, equipment and habitation structures would need to be resilient to such temperatures. These temperatures can cause materials to expand and contract, potentially leading to structural failure over time.

user_input: I'm creating a moving checklist and want to make sure my address is changed with every resource. What are some things I should add to my checklist?
assistant_response:
1. Change your address with all government agencies - 

There are a few government agencies you will need to notify when you move. Places such as the post office or social security office are a good place to start. Other institutions you may need to notify include your pension plan or the DMV. 

2. Change your address with all healthcare services and providers - 

If you plan to stay with the same healthcare providers, all you will need to do is request to update your files with your new address. However, suppose you are moving farther away and transferring to a new doctor. In that case, you must obtain your medical records from your previous providers, such as your doctor, dentist, veterinarian, and other specialists.

3. Change your address with all personal sources and contacts - 

There are several personal sources that you will need to give your change of address to, such as your friends and family members, as well as anyone in your community you want to stay in touch with. You will also need to reach out to any clubs or organizations your children belong to so that they can still be involved with them or join up with a different chapter in their new hometown.

4. Change your address with your insurance companies - 

Your insurance providers like your health insurance, life insurance, or auto insurance companies will need to know about your change of address. You can call them and speak with an agent to make sure your information is changed on time. Or, you may also be able to update the information online if possible. If applicable, don't forget to also change your address with other insurance companies such as dental insurance providers or your employment insurance program. 

5. Change your address with Utilities and other services if applicable -

The need to update your address with your utility companies and other service providers depends on if you will still be using the same provider at your new place of residence. Suppose you are moving to a new area where you will use a different company for your electricity or your water. If that is the case, you will need to let your current providers know the exact dates you want your utilities shut off at your old residence. You will also need to let your new providers know when you want your services turned on at your new home. 


6. Change your address with your financial services - 

With your financial services, along with updating your address, you may also want to consider transferring to a new branch or a different bank entirely if your current provider doesn't have a branch near your new place of residence. For other financial services, such as loan providers and credit card companies, most will allow you to change your address and other personal details online. Be sure to notify all of your credit card issuers of your new address. 


7. Change your address with online services - 

You will also need to update your online profiles and accounts with your various online services. It may be the most accessible category since you can make all these changes online without needing to fill out and drop off any paper forms. If you do a lot of online shopping, you likely have your current address saved on your accounts with your favorite online retailers as well.

user_input:
I need a Python script that takes the list below and calculates how many players are available for each day. Then find the day with the highest amount of player availability and show me the names of each player that is available for that day. 

players = [{'name': 'Bob', 'availability': ['Monday', 'Tuesday', 'Friday']}, {'name': 'Ben Tyson', 'availability': ['Tuesday', 'Thursday', 'Saturday']}, {'name': 'Joyce Sellers', 'availability': ['Monday', 'Wednesday', 'Friday', 'Saturday']}, {'name': 'Milly Rock', 'availability': ['Wednesday', 'Thursday', 'Sunday']}, {'name': 'Stephen Adams', 'availability': ['Thursday', 'Saturday']}, {'name': 'Joe Lynn', 'availability': ['Monday', 'Thursday']}, {'name': 'Latasha Bryan', 'availability': ['Monday', 'Sunday']}, {'name': 'Crystal Brewer', 'availability': ['Thursday', 'Friday', 'Saturday']}, {'name': 'JB Jr.', 'availability': ['Tuesday', 'Wednesday', 'Thursday', 'Sunday']}, {'name': 'Michel Trujillo', 'availability': ['Monday', 'Tuesday', 'Wednesday']}]
assistant_response:
I can assist you with that. Here is a Python script that calculates the number of players available for each day, calculates the day with the most available players, and prints out the player names who are available that day.

```Python
# Calculate how many players are available for each day
def populate_availability(players_list, availability):
    for player in players_list:
        for day in player['availability']:
            availability[day] += 1

# Calculate the day with the most available players
def find_best_day(availability_table_table):
    highest_num = 0
    best_day = ''
    for key, value in availability_table.items():
        if value > highest_num:
            highest_num = value
            best_day = key
    return best_day

# Calculate the player names that are available on the chosen day
def available_on_day(players_list, day):
    players_available = []
    for player in players_list:
        if day in player['availability']:
            players_available.append(player['name'])
    return players_available
            
days_available = {'Monday': 0, 'Tuesday': 0, 'Wednesday': 0, 'Thursday': 0, 'Friday': 0, 'Saturday': 0, 'Sunday': 0}
populate_availability(players, days_available)
game_day = find_best_day(days_available)
attending_game_day = available_on_day(players, game_day)

print(attending_game_day)
# Output: ['Ben Tyson', 'Milly Rock', 'Stephen Adams', 'Joe Lynn', 'Crystal Brewer', 'JB Jr.']
```

This script has 3 functions. 

1. populate_availability(players_list, availability) - This calculates how many players are available for each day. The first parameter `players_list` accepts a list of players. The second parameter `availability` accepts a dictionary of the days of the week paired with the availability count.
2. find_best_day(availability_table) - This calculates the day with the most available players. The parameter `availability_table` accepts a dictionary of the days of the week paired with the availability count.
3. available_on_day(players_list, day) This calculates the player names that are available on the chosen day

After the functions are defined, a default dictionary named `days_available` is created. Then each function is called and the final result containing the names of each player that is available for the game day is displayed.

user_input: I want to do a report on hot springs and how they are made. Can you write up a 100-200 words explanation of how they form and the possible benefits of them? Be sure to mention if there is more than one way for them to form but focus on the most common. Also include the areas where they are most likely to form.
assistant_response: There are several ways that hot springs can form, but most commonly form when water, either rainwater or groundwater, is heated by the magma that sits under the Earth's crust. The crust can form cracks and faults throughout its layers which allows water to flow deeper, closer to the magma, bringing its temperature up. This heated water is then forced back to the surface from the underground pressure creating hot springs. Another way for them to form is by rainwater being absorbed into the ground and heated by radioactive decay present throughout the crust before being forced back to the surface. In fact, water is heated by an additional 15 degrees Fahrenheit with every 1,000 feet it goes down. Many people credit hot springs with healing properties due to their high mineral content. During its time underground, the water of hot springs is known to have a high content of lithium, calcium, and radium. However, some hot springs can get dangerously hot or contain harmful chemicals and should be avoided.

user_input: Create a guided meditation prompt focused on the healing power of nature. It should include the following scenes: a lush forest, a flower-filled meadow, a babbling brook, and a clear, sunny sky. The focus should be on relieving stress and anxiety. The first paragraph will only be able preparative breathing and freeing the mind.
assistant_response:
Close your eyes and empty your mind. Free your thoughts and focus only on your breathing. Take a deep breath to the count of 4, 1-2-3-4, and release to the count of 4, 1-2-3-4. Repeat this two more times feeling the tension flowing down from the top of your head out the soles of your feet.

Picture yourself walking barefoot in a lush forest filled with strong trees. These trees hold so much life and provide clean air for you to breathe. Touch the tree and feel the life flow from its bark through the palms of your hands. Take a deep breath embracing the gift of strength it gives and releasing the feeling of weakness as you release this breath.

You continue your path through the forest and come to a babbling brook. You take a small step into the water feeling its coolness between your toes. You continue to walk deeper into the water allowing it to wash over your entire body cleansing every inch of your being, renewing your energy at the atomic level. Open your mouth and feel it refreshing you from the inside out. Take a deep breath welcoming the renewal it gives and releasing self-doubt and blame.

As you reach the other side of the brook witness the breathtaking sight before you; a meadow filled with beautiful flowers as far as your eye can see. You gaze up at the clear sky, basking in the warmth of the sun. Take a deep breath allowing it to recharge your core and release fatigue and weariness.

Lay down in the field and allow the fragrance of the flowers to envelope you. Light, fresh lavender mixed with sweet notes of vanilla invade your nostrils demanding a calmness to settle within you. Let go of all your anxiety. Nothing else matters at this moment. Your mind, body, and spirit are renewed.

Open your eyes and give yourself a few moments to acknowledge your new mindset. Continue to take deep breaths as you prepare to start or end your day. Go forward with the positivity you've instilled.

user_input: Paper has a deep-rooted history dating back to ancient times. What is the process by which the ancient Chinese first made paper?
assistant_response: The invention of paper is credited to the Chinese Han Dynasty court official, Cai Lun, in 105 CE. The process employed by the ancient Chinese involved several steps. First, they soaked discarded mulberry bark, hemp, rags, and fishnets in water, then they beat this mixture into a pulp. After the pulp was prepared, they poured it onto a flat piece of coarsely woven cloth which was set atop a framework, allowing the water to drain away. The wet mat of intertwined fibres remaining on the screen then underwent pressing and drying to form a sheet of paper.
